synopsis: Woo Jang-choon knocks over his woo woo cocktail
hybrid_definition: whoopsies=knocks over while drunk, either with arm or by bumping into with body
backstory: Woo Jang-choon was a Korean-Japanese botanist who achieved international scientific fame for engineering a double-flowered petunia. His Korean father, having been involved in the assassination of a Queen in Korea, fled to Japan and married a Japanese woman. Woo was discriminated against as a Korean, but still became a successful botanist. After WWII, the Japanese government refused to let him move to Korea, so he turned himself in to a Japanese ministry involved in rooting out people of Korean descent, and somehow got himself kicked out of Japan! He became a Korean hero. For the next 15 years, until his death, he led Korea's work in getting seeds and crops going in his struggling country, including during the Korean war. While growing up in Japan, his mother famously encouraged him to drink alcohol in order to propel his professional career. A Woo Woo is made of vodka, peach schnapps, and cranberry juice.

synopsis: Earl Warren serves a warrant as district attorney of Alameda County, CA in the 1920's
hybrid_definition: wires=hangs decorative seasonal lights on, or makes electric, with lights or motion; warrant=an arrest warrant for the subject (protagonist) of the sentence
backstory: Earl Warren (1891 - 1974) was the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court whose 'Warren Court' issued landmark civil rights rulings in the 50's and 60's (think 'Brown vs. Board of Education' and striking down laws against interracial marriage) and helped end McCarthyism. He had attended law school at UC Berkeley, then served as a District Attorney, then Attorney General of CA, then served as (republican) Governor of California (and the chair of the California Republican Party). After unsuccessful bids for vice president and president in 1948 and 1952, he was appointed to the Supreme Court by Dwight Eisenhower. Warren's father and mother were born in Norway and Sweden respectively, and had been married in Minneapolis before moving to California. (Thank God for solid Lutherans in American politics!) Warren did not receive a middle name; his father later commented that 'when you were born I was too poor to give you a middle name.' Warren opposed FDR's New Deal. He strictly enforced prohibition. synopsis: Wyatt Earp separates milk into cheese and whey using a Y-shaped pipe fixture, in the Old West
hybrid_definition: wyes=throws a metal wye plumbing fixture at something, or stuffs something into the fixture
tableau: Wyatt Earp, holding a wye full of whey, taking cover behind a rain barrel or other structure at the OK corral during a gunfight
backstory: Whey is a cloudy, yellowish liquid, packed with nutrients. More at end. Wyatt Earp lived all over the place. His family was in CA and Arizona, Missouri... At one point he lingered in Wyoming while the rest of his family continued their train journey back to Iowa or somewhere. Earp was a gambler, a brothel owner, a real estate dealer, and a lawman. He was involved in the famous shootout at the O.K. corral (in Tombstone, AZ) in which three outlaws were killed by Earp, two of his brothers, and Doc Holliday. Some outlaws from the same gang later maimed one, and killed another, of Earp's group. Earp lived a colorful life, and ended up in CA where he met enough of the right people to get himself immortalized in a book, then in movies. A wye is a pipe fixture used by plumbers, shaped like a lowercase-y. A wye is also a Y-shaped train track that takes up less space than a balloon loop, which is the other way to turn a train around. All about whey: Cows' milk has something like 70% casein proteins (KAY-seen, means cheese proteins) and 30% whey protein, whereas human milk is the reverse, 70% whey and 30% casein. To make cheese, rennin (the natural animal-derived enzyme) or rennet(artificial) is added to milk, curdling it. After some heating and processing, the whey (a liquid) is drained off. (Fun fact: feta is made from sheep's milk, and artisanal mozzarella is often made from Buffalo's milk). The whey is a cloudy, yellowish liquid. It is packed with nutrients, and so instead of tossing it out, many people like to add it to other recipes. The most common use is to put into bread and other recipes in place of water.

backstory: A chigger, or 'berry bug' or 'red bug', is a small, bright red bug. It looks like a cross between a spider, a pin cushion, and a red blood cell. At 1/150 of an inch, they are barely visible to the naked eye, but can be seen as a red spot when they are clustered together. The juvenile forms, which embed their mouth parts in you causing intense irritation and a wheal, have six legs, while the (harmless) adults have eight. 'Bug juice', or red juice, gets its name from the fact that some red juice actually is colored with a dye extracted from bugs.  Cochineal, or 'Natural Red 4', is a common red dye extracted from the cochineal bug. Marc Chagall was a painter born in modern-day Belarus who spent his life and career in France. Pablo Picasso said of him: 'When Matisse dies, Chagall will be the only painter left who understands what colour is.'  Chagall was born into the Jewish community of a small city in Belarus. His background and life is as colorful as his paintings. His father did back-breaking work, and there were no artists in the family, or art works either. Chagall once barely escaped a pogrom in his town. He married his sweetheart, who became his muse. He left the town for St. Petersburg and eventually made his career in France. He would paint naked and eat half a herring a day to save money on food and laundry. During the Nazi occupation of France he spent six years in New York but never learned English. 'It took me thirty years to learn bad French, why should I try to learn English?'  He painted Jewish themes, and has a double reputation as an important Jewish painter and as a world-class painter independent of his Jewish background.

Charlie was in a bad car accident early in his career, which led to his morphine and heroin addiction. He was also an alcoholic. His 3-year old daughter died in 1954. It's hard to say enough good things about Yo-yo Ma, so let's keep it brief with a wikipedia quote:  'Yo-Yo Ma (born October 7, 1955) is an American cellist. Born in Paris, France, to Chinese parents and educated in New York City, he was a child prodigy, performing from the age of four and a half. He graduated from the Juilliard School and Harvard University, and has performed as a soloist with orchestras around the world. He has recorded more than 90 albums and received 18 Grammy Awards.'  Yo-yo's ARE ancient, but their use as weapons is a (pretty unconvincing) myth. On a Greek vase from 400 B.C.E. there is an image of a boy playing with what looks like a yo-yo. They were popular in Europ in the 1700's. In 1928, Pedro Flores, from the Philippines, opened up a yoyo factory in California and sold millions of them before being bought out by Donald F. Duncan. The Filipino innovation that Flores used was to loop the string around the axle, not tie it, so that now it could spin freely at the bottom and 'sleep'. In 1962, Duncan sold 45 million yo-yo's in a country with 40 million children.

backstory: yomping is a word used by British Royal Marines to describe a long, arduous walk carrying full gear, which is something soldiers frequently have to do. Abbie Hoffman was one of the leading members of the 'Yippies', an activist group in the 1960's known for street theater. One of Abbie Hoffman's stunts was to go to the New York Stock Exchange and throw dollar bills into the gallery, which a bunch of traders actually started grabbing up. The FBI tried to block publication of Hoffman's book 'Woodstock Nation' because there was a recipe for incendiary devices that Hoffman suggested could be attached to dogs who were to be set loose in crowds. The recipe was from an army field manual, but it turned out the field manual was available to the public, so Hoffman didn't break any laws publishing it. Anyway, I picture Abbie Hoffman weaponizing dogs, and carrying a dog into a protest or through a battlefield.

synopsis: Tasha Yar leaves behind a shipment of medicine
hybrid_definition: yores=discards object by throwing it over the shoulder while walking away forward
backstory: yores has been 'verbified' here, to mean:  to discard an object so that it now belongs to 'days of yore'. Yarrow is a medicinal plant, sometimes called 'wound wort' for its use in treating cuts and abrasions. In the Star Trek episode 'Symbiosis', Tasha Yar beams the cargo of a damaged freighter to the Enterprise, then beams aboard the small crew. The cargo turns out to be medicine, which THEN turns out to be not medicine but a narcotic drug. Long story. During the course of the episode, Tasha Yar explains the ills of drug use to Wesley Crusher (in an easily googleable scene). At the end of the episode, they leave the crew members and drugs behind them, to let them muddle their way through their own mess. (Captain Picard is anxious to put this mission far behind them, and they set course for the unexplored Opperline system). Tasha Yar was only in the show for the first season. She decided to leave, and her character was unceremoniously murdered by a bad alien. Yar appeared in various subsequent Star Trek franchise shows in intermittent roles. Denise Crosby, who played Yar, went on to direct and star in the movie 'Trekkies'. Fun fact: She is one of 20 grandchildren of uber-famous singer and recording artist Bing Crosby. Denise was 19 when Bing Crosby died, but he never cultivated relationships with his grandchildren and she never met him.

synopsis: Yu the Great laughs at Nanguo, who plays the yu badly
hybrid_definition: yuk-yuk's=laughs at the object, which has been placed in jello as a prank (think staplers in jello); yu=an ancient Chinese wind instrument
backstory: This is a mash-up of 3,000-year-old Chinese history and 1,000-year old Chinese history, so bear with me... Yu the Great, 2000 BC, is famous for two things: Being the first dynastic ruler of China (starting a 3000-year period which lasted up until 100 years ago), and figuring out how to get flood waters under control.  The Yu is an ancient (1,000 year-old) Chinese wind instrument similar to the modern-day Sheng. You blow into a tube, which goes into a bowl-shapes vessel, and a bunch of pipes (with reeds) come up vertically out of the bowl.  'Although the yu is now obsolete, it is known to most Chinese speakers through the saying 'Lan yu chong shu' meaning 'to fill a position without having the necessary qualifications.' The saying is derived from the story of Nanguo, a man who joined the royal court orchestra of King Xuan of Qi (319 BC–300 BC), the ruler of the State of Qi (Shandong province) as a yu player. Although the man did not actually know how to play this instrument, he knew that the orchestra had no fewer than 300 yu players, so he felt secure that he could simply pretend to play, and thus collect a musician's salary. Upon the king's death, Nanguo was eventually exposed as an impostor when the king's son Min (300 BC–283 BC), who had succeeded his father as king, requested that the musicians play individually rather than as an ensemble. On the night before he was to play, Nanguo fled the palace, never to return.'

synopsis: Qi Yuwu turns a Christmas tree to the perfect angle for the room
hybrid_definition: yaws=spins object, either by slapping it so that it spins away from person, or setting it on a lazy susan and spinning it; yew=a yew shrub
backstory: An airplane can rotate in three directions. If the nose goes up, that's 'pitch'. If a wing goes down for a banking turn, that's 'roll'. If the whole aircraft turns to the left or right without banking, that's 'yaw'. If a giant spun an airplane that was sitting on a runway, that would be a lot of yaw.  The yew is a classification of trees and shrubs. They are evergreens and have cones. Their red berry is, somehow, the cone. Yew trees are tall and very wide. Yew shrubs are a common decoration in a garden. All parts of the yew are toxic, and the yew was known in ancient literature as a means of suicide when facing military defeat.  Qi Yuwu is an actor in Singapore, married to another famous actor, Joanne Peh. They do celebrate Christmas, based on images and videos ('Warmth of Christmas', karoke with family) available.

legacy_sentence: Zarathustra zithers a zither (Zoroaster plays a zither) [zithers=serenades, plays for] <modern day Iran> Zarathustra a.k.a. Zoroaster, Iranian founder of Zoroastrianism, possibly 1500 B.C., more at end. A zither looks like a hammered dulcimer. Many strings, strung over a flat body with no neck. But it is plucked, not hammered. The words 'zither' and 'guitar' both derive from the Greek 'cithara'. (Zoroastrian music: still a thing). Zarathustra: name MAY mean 'with old camels', 'with angry camels', 'one who can manage camels'. Zarathustra was likely to be his real name, Zoroaster being a later Greek-ified name (meaning 'undiluted star'). Founder of Zoroastrianism, important also to people of the Baha'i faith. Ancient prophet of Iran, 2nd millennium B.C., possibly 1500 B.C., but could be from even older. No one knows. OED calls him the world's first philosopher. He wrote the 'Gathas', a text which may or may not be contemporary with the Rigveda. He was the first to articulate the following concepts: Monotheism, heaven, hell, free will. 'The religion founded by Zoroaster was the first major world religion and has had significant influence on other religious and philosophical systems, including Christianity, Judaism, Islam, Buddhism, the Bahá'í Faith, Gnosticism and Greek philosophy'

synopsis: Travis Zajac welds the sewing machine he will use to mend his own uniform
hybrid_definition: zojans=mends a tear in; Zoje=picture the Zoje sewing machine with the brand name 'ZOJE' across its main body
tableau: Travis Zajac in the locker room, with a hockey stick
backstory: Zojan (original word: Zhongjian) is a brand of hand-held mini-welder from China. (Welding isn't typically about mending tears, more about joining two different pieces, but it will do.) Zoje is a brand of sewing machine from China, established 1994, with offices all over the world. Their machines are classified as industrial, which just means they're a little bigger and can handle thicker fabrics. Travis Zajac, from Winnipeg, is an NHL hockey player with the New Jersey Devils. He looks a bit like Paul Rudd (Ant Man). He has played there for 14 seasons and has played 1000 games, which is a big number. He is a center and scores lots of goals. Like many hockey players, he is humble and gives credit to his team. This sentence, about him doing detail work, is a reference to his heads-down humility. Zajac likes to be able to see the clock and whiteboard from his locker without turning around, during a game. He was once amazed to see fellow teammate hockey star Jagr eating (non-nutritional) muffins at his locker. Zajac on stats: 'I think for me, as soon as you start thinking about stats and where you are in goals, even during the year itself, it can really take away from your game and what's important.' Zajac on doing the work: 'I worked a lot on strength training. I wanted to get bigger and knew that the competition level would be intense, as some guys are 10-to-15 years older than me.
